Award.AwardTitle: CS 10K: Collaborative Research: Priming the PUMP - Preparing the Upper Midwest for Principles of Computer Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Marquette University, in collaboration with the University of Wisconsin La Crosse, proposes the PUMP-CS Project (Preparing the Upper Midwest for Principles of Computer Science). PUMP-CS will provide a two-track professional development (PD) sequence for endorsing in-service and pre-service teachers--regardless of their prior CS-specific knowledge--to teach the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) or Computer Science Principles (AP CSP) curricula in their classrooms. The first track prepares in-service teachers to lead 9th- or 10th-grade level ECS, which integrates an inquiry- and equity-based pedagogy to convey solid CS content while appealing to a more diverse student population than traditional CS offerings. The second track includes a methods course, Teaching Computer Science (TCS), which enables both pre-service and in-service teachers to add a CS-specific endorsement to their primary certification, while continuing to promote pedagogical reform. This CS methods course is a "missing link" preventing teachers from earning the CS endorsement required to teach a course with more than 25% programming content, (e.g. AP CS or CSP). The planned hybrid/online format for TCS will allow remote teachers in "density-challenged" regions to participate in a supportive learning community as they master the content and methods required. The project team includes members from universities, the Wisconsin-Dairyland chapter of the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA), officials from the Department of Public Instruction (DPI), and teachers and administrators from districts across the state. Collectively, they have the diverse institutional knowledge necessary to drive change in state licensure and curriculum standards, to match college-level courses at key universities to the STEM student pipeline, to promote new content and structure for CS teacher preparation, and to rigorously assess the results of this large-scale intervention on teacher education and student learning. This proposed work will lead to regional, sustainable institutional change to improve CS education, and scalable teacher preparation materials ready for other institutions to adopt, and its careful assessment will explore deeper questions of when and how CS teacher preparation can be most effective, and how those lessons can be leveraged in other STEM teaching fields.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The most concrete goal of the PUMP-CS Project was to prepare at least 100 high school teachers for classroom placement with both professional development (PD) and endorsements to effectively teach either the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) or Advanced Placement Computer Science Principles (AP CSP) national computer science curricula.  In four years, we exceeded this goal by 22%, bringing new CS courses to thousands of Wisconsin high school students in dozens of urban, suburban and rural districts across the state.  In academic year 2016-2017, 42 Wisconsin teachers offered the AP CSP course, nearly all of those teachers participants from the various professional development tracks offered by this project.

In December 2016, our alternative certification pathway was approved by the Wisconsin Department of Public Instruction. Called a "model alternative licensure program" by the state reviewers, this pathway allows in-service teachers to earn their CS license through professional development courses and content and pedagogy portfolios that demonstrate their mastery of the necessary knowledge and skills. This new pathway is a collaboration between Marquette University and the Milwaukee Teacher Education Center (MTEC), with the Wisconsin-Dairyland chapter of the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) providing thesupply of clinical classroom observers and mentors. Now established, this program is designed to be self-sustaining after the funding period for the grant ends, with area school districts pooling their resources to provide the ongoing PD courses and mentoring needed by new CS teachers.

Our data show substantial increases in CS enrollments statewide, concentrated in schools with teachers who participated in our program.  The introduction of ECS in Wisconsin has had much more of an impact on schools with a higher level of economic disadvantage. We have seen that schools that are more economically disadvantaged were less likely to have offered any CS courses before the initiative, and that adding ECS led to a wider variety of CS courses for those schools after the initial intervention year. Schools which were less disadvantaged were more likely to have already been offering CS courses, and the addition of ECS often did not significantly change their enrollment percentages.

Overall, ECS students achieved large learning gains from pre-test to post-test, and those learning gains were spread equitably across gender and race/ethnicity. These learning gains were larger for teachers with more experience teaching ECS, which suggests the extended professional development program provides opportunities for teachers to continue to improve their practices. These results also imply the importance for principals to maintain consistency in ECS teaching assignments from one year to the next.  Prior research on expectancy-value suggests that the overall increased expectancy-value derived from the ECS course experience will lead to increases in the number of students who pursue computer science.

A fifth cohort of ECS teachers will be starting ECS PD in summer 2018, including both large numbers of new Milwaukee Public Schools teachers and teachers from elsewhere in the state. MPS teachers are covered by a new NSF STEM+C grant, but non-MPS teachers are sustaining the program through nominal registration fees normally covered by their school disctricts.  Moreover, the explosive success of ECS over the past four years has helped drive enrollment in new PD tracks specifically geared to high school AP CSP courses, middle school computer science courses, and specialty experiences such as cybersecurity camps. Several regional cooperative education service agencies (called "CESAs" in Wisconsin) are becoming involved in promoting and supporting CS PD for their constituent districts, as well as helping local administrators to understand and unpack the new CS academic standards.


Last Modified: 06/06/2018
Modified by: Dennis Brylow
